title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: R package tsfeatures provides methods extracting various features time series data.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: stable version R CRAN can installed usual way: can install development version Github :

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: function tsfeatures() computes tibble time series features list time series. default functions tsfeatures uses compute features frequency, stl_features, entropy acf_features. can produce one features. Detailed information features included tsfeatures package described . Functions packages, user-defined functions, may also used.
code: mylist <- list(sunspot.year, WWWusage, AirPassengers, USAccDeaths) tsfeatures(mylist) #> # A tibble: 4 × 20 #>   frequency nperiods seasonal_period trend      spike linearity curvature e_acf1 #>       <dbl>    <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1         1        0               1 0.125    2.10e-5      3.58      1.11  0.793 #> 2         1        0               1 0.985    3.01e-8      4.45      1.10  0.774 #> 3        12        1              12 0.991    1.46e-8     11.0       1.09  0.509 #> 4        12        1              12 0.802    9.15e-7     -2.12      2.85  0.258 #> # ℹ 12 more variables: e_acf10 <dbl>, entropy <dbl>, x_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   x_acf10 <dbl>, diff1_acf1 <dbl>, diff1_acf10 <dbl>, diff2_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   diff2_acf10 <dbl>, seasonal_strength <dbl>, peak <dbl>, trough <dbl>, #> #   seas_acf1 <dbl> # Function from outside of tsfeatures package being used is.monthly <- function(x){   frequency(x) == 12 } tsfeatures(mylist, features = "is.monthly") #> # A tibble: 4 × 1 #>   is.monthly #>        <dbl> #> 1          0 #> 2          0 #> 3          1 #> 4          1

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: compute autocorrelation function series, differenced series, twice-differenced series. acf_features produces vector comprising first autocorrelation coefficient case, sum squares first 10 autocorrelation coefficients case.
code: acf_features(AirPassengers) #>      x_acf1     x_acf10  diff1_acf1 diff1_acf10  diff2_acf1 diff2_acf10  #>   0.9480473   5.6700871   0.3028553   0.4088376  -0.1910059   0.2507803  #>   seas_acf1  #>   0.7603950

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: arch_stat Computes statistic based Lagrange Multiplier (LM) test Engle (1982) autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (ARCH). statistic returned \(R^2\) value autoregressive model order specified lags applied \(x^2\).

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: autocorrelation feature set software package hctsa ac_9 autocorrelation lag 9. embed2_incircle gives proportion points inside given circular boundary 2-d embedding space. firstmin_ac returns time first minimum autocorrelation function. trev_num returns numerator trev function time series, normalized nonlinear autocorrelation. time lag set 1. motiftwo_entro3 finds local motifs binary symbolization time series. Coarse-graining performed. Time-series values mean given 1, mean 0. motiftwo_entro3 returns entropy words binary alphabet length 3. walker_propcross simulates hypothetical walker moving time domain. hypothetical particle (‘walker’) moves response values time series point. walker narrows gap value time series 10. walker_propcross returns fraction time series length walker crosses time series.
code: autocorr_features(AirPassengers) #> embed2_incircle_1 embed2_incircle_2              ac_9       firstmin_ac  #>         0.0000000         0.0000000         0.6709483         8.0000000  #>          trev_num   motiftwo_entro3  walker_propcross  #>     -4902.1958042         1.1302445         0.2027972

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: binarize_mean converts input vector binarized version. Time-series values mean given 1, mean 0.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: compengine calculate features used CompEngine database, using method introduced package kctsa. features involved can grouped autocorrelation, prediction, stationarity, distribution, scaling, can computed using autocorr_features, pred_features, station_features, dist_features, scal_features.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: crossing points defined number times time series crosses median line.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: distribution feature set hctsa package. scaling feature set hctsa. histogram_mode measures mode data vector using histograms given number bins (default 10) suggestion. outlierinclude_mdrmd measures median outliers included calculation according specified rule, outliers furthest mean. threshold including time-series data points analysis increases zero maximum deviation, increments 0.01*sigma (default), sigma standard deviation time series. threshold, proportion time series points included median calculated, outputs algorithm measure statistical quantities change extreme points included calculation. outlierinclude_mdrmd essentially returns median median range indices.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: spectral entropy Shannon entropy \[   -\int^\pi_{-\pi}\hat{f}(\lambda)\log\hat{f}(\lambda) d\lambda, \] \(\hat{f}(\lambda)\) estimate spectral density data. measures “forecastability” time series, low values indicate high signal--noise ratio, large values occur series difficult forecast.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: firstzero_ac returns first zero crossing autocorrelation function.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: flat_spots computed dividing sample space time series ten equal-sized intervals, computing maximum run length within single interval.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: heterogeneity features measure heterogeneity time series. First, pre-whiten time series remove mean, trend, autoregressive (AR) information (Barbour & Parker 2014). fit \(GARCH(1,1)\) model pre-whitened time series, \(x_t\), measure autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) effects. residuals model, \(z_t\), also measured ARCH effects using second \(GARCH(1,1)\) model. arch_acf sum squares first 12 autocorrelations \(\{x^2_t\}\). garch_acf sum squares first 12 autocorrelations \(\{z^2_t\}\). arch_r2 \(R^2\) value AR model applied \(\{x^2_t\}\). garch_r2 \(R^2\) value AR model applied \(\{z^2_t\}\). statistics obtained \(\{x^2_t\}\) ARCH effects, \(\{z^2_t\}\) GARCH effects. Note two \(R^2\) values used Lagrange-multiplier test Engle (1982), sum squared autocorrelations used Ljung-Box test proposed Ljung & Box (1978).

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: holt_parameters Estimate smoothing parameter level-alpha smoothing parameter trend-beta Holt’s linear trend method. hw_parameters considers additive seasonal trend: ETS(,,) model, returning vector 3 values: alpha, beta gamma.
code: holt_parameters(AirPassengers) #>        alpha         beta  #> 0.9998999495 0.0001000188 hw_parameters(AirPassengers) #>        alpha         beta        gamma  #> 0.9934803629 0.0001911792 0.0005800325

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: use measure long-term memory time series (hurst), computed 0.5 plus maximum likelihood estimate fractional differencing order \(d\) given Haslett & Raftery (1989). add 0.5 make consistent Hurst coefficient. Note fractal dimension can estimated \(D = 2 - \text{hurst}\).

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: Stability lumpiness two time series features based tiled (non-overlapping) windows. Means variances produced tiled windows. stability variance means, lumpiness variance variances.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: three features compute features time series based sliding (overlapping) windows. max_level_shift finds largest mean shift two consecutive windows. max_var_shift finds largest variance shift two consecutive windows. max_kl_shift finds largest shift Kulback-Leibler divergence two consecutive windows. feature returns vector 2 values: size shift, time index shift.
code: max_level_shift(AirPassengers) #>  max_level_shift time_level_shift  #>             54.5            127.0 max_var_shift(AirPassengers) #>  max_var_shift time_var_shift  #>       2342.152        117.000 max_kl_shift(AirPassengers) #>  max_kl_shift time_kl_shift  #>     0.1210444   132.0000000

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: nonlinearity coefficient computed using modification statistic used Teräsvirta’s nonlinearity test. Teräsvirta’s test uses statistic \(X^2=T\log(\text{SSE}1/\text{SSE}0)\) SSE1 SSE0 sum squared residuals nonlinear linear autoregression respectively. non-ergodic, instead, define \(10X^2/T\) converge value indicating extent nonlinearity \(T\rightarrow\infty\). takes large values series nonlinear, values around 0 series linear.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: compute partial autocorrelation function series, differenced series, second-order differenced series. pacf_features produces vector comprising sum squares first 5 partial autocorrelation coefficients case.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: prediction feature set hctsa package. first two elements obtained localsimple_taurus different forecast methods (mean, LS fit). third sampen_first. Simple predictors using past trainLength values time series predict next value. localsimple_taures returns first zero crossing autocorrelation function residuals Simple local time-series forecasting. sampen_first returns first Sample Entropy time series embedding dimension set 5 threshold set 0.3. sampenc underlying function calculate first sample entropy optional dimension threshold settings.
code: pred_features(AirPassengers) #>  localsimple_mean1 localsimple_lfitac       sampen_first  #>                  2                  3                Inf sampenc(AirPassengers, M = 5, r = 0.3) #> [1] Inf

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: scaling feature set hctsa. fluctanal_prop_r1 implements fluctuation analysis. fits polynomial order 1 returns range. order fluctuations 2, corresponding root mean square fluctuations.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: stationary feature set hctsa. std1st_der returns standard deviation first derivative time series. 100 time-series segments length l selected random time series mean first zero-crossings autocorrelation function segment calculated using spreadrandomlocal_meantaul.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: stl_features Computes various measures trend seasonality time series based STL decomposition. mstl function used decomposition. nperiods number seasonal periods data (determined frequency observation, observations ) set 1 non-seasonal data. seasonal_period vector seasonal periods set 1 non-seasonal data. size location peaks troughs seasonal component used compute strength peaks (peak) strength trough (trough). rest features modifications features used Kang, Hyndman & Smith-Miles (2017). extend STL decomposition approach (Cleveland et al.1990) handle multiple seasonalities. Thus, decomposition contains trend, \(M\) seasonal components remainder component: \[   x_t=f_t+s_{1,t}+\cdots+s_{M.t}+e_t, \] \(f_t\) smoothed trend component, \(s_{,t}\) \(\)th seasonal component \(e_t\) remainder component. components estimated iteratively. Let \(s^{(k)}_{,t}\) estimate \(s_i,t\) \(k\)th iteration, initial values given \(s^{(0)}_{,t}=0\). apply STL decomposition \(x_t-\sum^{j=1}_{j\neq1}{}^{^{M}}s^{k-1}_{j,t}\) obtained updated estimates \(s^{(k)}_{,t}\) \(k=1,2,\ldots\). practice, converges quickly two iterations required. allow procedure applied automatically, set seasonal window span STL 21 cases. non-seasonal time series, simply estimate \(x_t=f_t+e_t\) \(f_t\) computed using Friedman’s “super smoother” (Friedman 1984). Strength trend (trend) strength seasonality (seasonal.strength) defined \[   \text{trend} = 1-\frac{\text{Var}(e_t)}{\text{Var}(f_t+e_t)}\quad \text{}\quad \text{seasonal.strength}=1-\frac{\text{Var}(e_t)}{\text{Var}(s_{,t}+e_t)}. \] values less 0, set 0, values greater 1 set 1. non-seasonal time series seasonal.strength 0. seasonal time series, seasonal.strength M-vector, M number periods. analogous way strength trend seasonality defined Wang, Smith & Hyndman (2006), Hyndman, Wang & Laptev (2015) Kang, Hyndman & Smith-Miles (2017). spike measures “spikiness” time series, computed variance leave-one-variances remainder component \(e_t\). linearity curvature measures linearity curvature time series calculated based coefficients orthogonal quadratic regression. compute autocorrelation function \(e_t\), e_acf1 e_acf10 contain first autocorrelation coefficient sum first ten squared autocorrelation coefficients.
code: stl_features(AirPassengers) #>          nperiods   seasonal_period             trend             spike  #>         1.0000000        12.0000000         0.9909550         3.0277699  #>         linearity         curvature            e_acf1           e_acf10  #>      1325.3317266       131.0646804         0.5091751         0.9303664  #> seasonal_strength              peak            trough  #>         0.9406725         7.0000000        11.0000000

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: unitroot_kpss vector comprising statistic KPSS unit root test linear trend lag one, unitroot_pp statistic “Z-alpha” version PP unit root test constant trend lag one.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: Computes proporton zeros time series.

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: replicate analysis Hyndman, Wang & Laptev (ICDM 2015). However, note crossing_points, peak trough defined differently tsfeatures package Hyndman et al (2015) paper. features .
code: library(tsfeatures) library(dplyr)  yahoo <- yahoo_data() hwl <- bind_cols(          tsfeatures(yahoo,            c("acf_features","entropy","lumpiness",              "flat_spots","crossing_points")),          tsfeatures(yahoo,"stl_features", s.window='periodic', robust=TRUE),          tsfeatures(yahoo, "max_kl_shift", width=48),          tsfeatures(yahoo,            c("mean","var"), scale=FALSE, na.rm=TRUE),          tsfeatures(yahoo,            c("max_level_shift","max_var_shift"), trim=TRUE)) %>%   select(mean, var, x_acf1, trend, linearity, curvature,          seasonal_strength, peak, trough,          entropy, lumpiness, spike, max_level_shift, max_var_shift, flat_spots,          crossing_points, max_kl_shift, time_kl_shift) # 2-d Feature space library(ggplot2) hwl_pca <- hwl %>%   na.omit() %>%   prcomp(scale=TRUE) hwl_pca$x %>%   as_tibble() %>%   ggplot(aes(x=PC1, y=PC2)) +     geom_point()

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: Compute features used Kang, Hyndman & Smith-Miles (IJF 2017). Note trend ACF1 computed differently non-seasonal data tsfeatures package Kang et al (2017). tsfeatures uses mstl uses supsmu trend calculation non-seasonal data, whereas Kang et al used penalized regression spline computed using mgcv instead. features .
code: library(tsfeatures) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(forecast)  M3data <- purrr::map(Mcomp::M3,   function(x) {       tspx <- tsp(x$x)       ts(c(x$x,x$xx), start=tspx[1], frequency=tspx[3])   }) khs_stl <- function(x,...) {   lambda <- BoxCox.lambda(x, lower=0, upper=1, method='loglik')   y <- BoxCox(x, lambda)   c(stl_features(y, s.window='periodic', robust=TRUE, ...), lambda=lambda) } khs <- bind_cols(   tsfeatures(M3data, c("frequency", "entropy")),   tsfeatures(M3data, "khs_stl", scale=FALSE)) %>%   select(frequency, entropy, trend, seasonal_strength, e_acf1, lambda) %>%   replace_na(list(seasonal_strength=0)) %>%   rename(     Frequency = frequency,     Entropy = entropy,     Trend = trend,     Season = seasonal_strength,     ACF1 = e_acf1,     Lambda = lambda) %>%   mutate(Period = as.factor(Frequency)) # Fig 1 of paper khs %>%   select(Period, Entropy, Trend, Season, ACF1, Lambda) %>%   GGally::ggpairs() # 2-d Feature space (Top of Fig 2) khs_pca <- khs %>%   select(-Period) %>%   prcomp(scale=TRUE) khs_pca$x %>%   as_tibble() %>%   bind_cols(Period=khs$Period) %>%   ggplot(aes(x=PC1, y=PC2)) +     geom_point(aes(col=Period))

title: Introduction to the tsfeatures package
text: Barbour, . J., & Parker, R. L. (2014). psd: Adaptive, sine multitaper power spectral density estimation R. Computers & Geosciences, 63, 1-8. Cleveland, R. B., Cleveland, W. S., McRae, J. E., & Terpenning, . (1990). STL: Seasonal-Trend Decomposition. Journal Official Statistics, 6(1), 3-73. Engle, R. F. (1982). Autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity estimates variance United Kingdom inflation. Econometrica: Journal Econometric Society, 987-1007. Friedman, JH (1984). variable span scatterplot smoother. Technical Report 5. Laboratory Computational Statistics, Stanford University. Haslett, J., & Raftery, . E. (1989). Space-time modelling long-memory dependence: Assessing Ireland’s wind power resource. Applied Statistics, 1-50. Hyndman, R. J., Wang, E., & Laptev, N. (2015, November). Large-scale unusual time series detection. Data Mining Workshop (ICDMW), 2015 IEEE International Conference (pp. 1616-1619). IEEE. Kang, Y., Hyndman, R. J., & Li, F. (2018). GRATIS: GeneRAting TIme Series diverse controllable characteristics. Kang, Y., Hyndman, R. J., & Smith-Miles, K. (2017). Visualising forecasting algorithm performance using time series instance spaces. International Journal Forecasting, 33(2), 345-358. Ljung, G. M., & Box, G. E. (1978). measure lack fit time series models. Biometrika, 65(2), 297-303. Wang, X, KA Smith & RJ Hyndman (2006). Characteristic-based clustering time series data. Data Mining Knowledge Discovery 13(3), 335–364.

title: Time Series Feature Extraction
text: R package tsfeatures provides methods extracting various features time series data.

title: Time Series Feature Extraction
text: can install stable version R CRAN. can install development version Github :

title: Time Series Feature Extraction
code: library(tsfeatures) mylist <- list(sunspot.year, WWWusage, AirPassengers, USAccDeaths) myfeatures <- tsfeatures(mylist) myfeatures #> # A tibble: 4 × 20 #>   frequency nperiods seasonal_period trend      spike linearity curvature e_acf1 #>       <dbl>    <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1         1        0               1 0.125    2.10e-5      3.58      1.11  0.793 #> 2         1        0               1 0.985    3.01e-8      4.45      1.10  0.774 #> 3        12        1              12 0.991    1.46e-8     11.0       1.09  0.509 #> 4        12        1              12 0.802    9.15e-7     -2.12      2.85  0.258 #> # ℹ 12 more variables: e_acf10 <dbl>, entropy <dbl>, x_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   x_acf10 <dbl>, diff1_acf1 <dbl>, diff1_acf10 <dbl>, diff2_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   diff2_acf10 <dbl>, seasonal_strength <dbl>, peak <dbl>, trough <dbl>, #> #   seas_acf1 <dbl>

what: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: Computes spectral entropy univariate normalized spectral density, estimated using AR model.

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: x univariate time series

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: non-negative real value spectral entropy \(H_s(x_t)\).

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: spectral entropy equals Shannon entropy spectral density \(f_x(\lambda)\) stationary process \(x_t\): $$ H_s(x_t) = - \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f_x(\lambda) \log f_x(\lambda) d \lambda, $$ density normalized \(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f_x(\lambda) d \lambda = 1\). estimate \(f(\lambda)\) can obtained using spec.ar burg method.

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: Jerry D. Gibson Jaewoo Jung (2006). “Interpretation Spectral Entropy Based Upon Rate Distortion Functions”. IEEE International Symposium Information Theory, pp. 277-281. Goerg, G. M. (2013). “Forecastable Component Analysis”. Proceedings 30th International Conference Machine Learning (PMLR) 28 (2): 64-72, 2013. Available https://proceedings.mlr.press/v28/goerg13.html.

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Spectral entropy of a time series — entropy
code: entropy(rnorm(1000)) #> entropy  #>       1  entropy(lynx) #>   entropy  #> 0.7331515  entropy(sin(1:20)) #>     entropy  #> 0.003481715

title: Heterogeneity coefficients — heterogeneity
text: Computes various measures heterogeneity time series. First series pre-whitened using AR model give new series y. fit GARCH(1,1) model y obtain residuals, e. four measures heterogeneity : (1) sum squares first 12 autocorrelations \(y^2\); (2) sum squares first 12 autocorrelations \(e^2\); (3) \(R^2\) value AR model applied \(y^2\); (4) \(R^2\) value AR model applied \(e^2\). statistics obtained \(y^2\) ARCH effects, \(e^2\) GARCH effects.

title: Heterogeneity coefficients — heterogeneity
Heterogeneity coefficients — heterogeneity
text: x univariate time series

title: Heterogeneity coefficients — heterogeneity
text: vector numeric values.

title: Heterogeneity coefficients — heterogeneity
text: Yanfei Kang Rob J Hyndman

what: tsfeatures: Time Series Feature Extraction — tsfeatures-package
title: tsfeatures: Time Series Feature Extraction — tsfeatures-package
text: Methods extracting various features time series data. features provided Hyndman, Wang Laptev (2013) doi:10.1109/ICDMW.2015.104 , Kang, Hyndman Smith-Miles (2017) doi:10.1016/j.ijforecast.2016.09.004  Fulcher, Little Jones (2013) doi:10.1098/rsif.2013.0048 . Features include spectral entropy, autocorrelations, measures strength seasonality trend, . Users can also define feature functions.

title: tsfeatures: Time Series Feature Extraction — tsfeatures-package
text: Maintainer: Rob Hyndman Rob.Hyndman@monash.edu (ORCID) Authors: Yanfei Kang (ORCID) Pablo Montero-Manso p.montero.manso@udc.es Mitchell O'Hara-Wild (ORCID) Thiyanga Talagala (ORCID) Earo Wang (ORCID) Yangzhuoran Yang Fin.Yang@monash.edu contributors: Souhaib Ben Taieb [contributor] Cao Hanqing [contributor] D K Lake [contributor] Nikolay Laptev [contributor] J R Moorman [contributor] Bohan Zhang [contributor]

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
text: tsfeatures computes matrix time series features list time series

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
code: tsfeatures(   tslist,   features = c("frequency", "stl_features", "entropy", "acf_features"),   scale = TRUE,   trim = FALSE,   trim_amount = 0.1,   parallel = FALSE,   multiprocess = future::multisession,   na.action = na.pass,   ... )

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
text: tslist list univariate time series, class ts numeric vector. Alternatively, object class mts may used. features vector function names return numeric vectors features. features returned functions must named return one feature. Existing functions installed packages may used, package must loaded first. Functions must return result time series, even just NA. scale TRUE, time series scaled mean 0 sd 1 features computed. trim TRUE, time series trimmed trim_amount features computed. Values larger trim_amount absolute value set NA. trim_amount Default level trimming trim==TRUE. parallel TRUE, multiple cores (multiple sessions) used. speeds things large number time series. multiprocess function future package use parallel processing. Either multisession multicore. latter preferred Linux MacOS. na.action function handle missing values. Use na.interp estimate missing values. ... arguments get passed feature functions.

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
text: feature matrix (form tibble) row corresponding one time series tslist, column feature.

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Time series feature matrix — tsfeatures
code: mylist <- list(sunspot.year, WWWusage, AirPassengers, USAccDeaths) tsfeatures(mylist) #> # A tibble: 4 × 20 #>   frequency nperiods seasonal_period trend      spike linearity curvature e_acf1 #>       <dbl>    <dbl>           <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1         1        0               1 0.125    2.10e-5      3.58      1.11  0.793 #> 2         1        0               1 0.985    3.01e-8      4.45      1.10  0.774 #> 3        12        1              12 0.991    1.46e-8     11.0       1.09  0.509 #> 4        12        1              12 0.802    9.15e-7     -2.12      2.85  0.258 #> # ℹ 12 more variables: e_acf10 <dbl>, entropy <dbl>, x_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   x_acf10 <dbl>, diff1_acf1 <dbl>, diff1_acf10 <dbl>, diff2_acf1 <dbl>, #> #   diff2_acf10 <dbl>, seasonal_strength <dbl>, peak <dbl>, trough <dbl>, #> #   seas_acf1 <dbl>

title: Unit Root Test Statistics — unitroot_kpss
text: unitroot_kpss computes statistic Kwiatkowski et al. unit root test using default settings ur.kpss function. unitroot_pp computes statistic Phillips-Perron unit root test using default settings ur.pp function.
